tanks.note: Infantry division with no organic armor. Supported by 7th Royal Tank Regiment (Matilda IIs) during Bardia/Tobruk assaults.

terrain_conditions: Coastal Libya - fortified positions (Bardia, Tobruk), desert advance
weather_impact: Favorable winter conditions for offensive operations. Mild temperatures (10-25°C) enabling sustained assaults. Occasional rain improving water availability. Division conducted three major assaults Q1: Bardia (3-5 Jan), Tobruk (21-22 Jan), Benghazi pursuit (Feb).

combat_status.notes: 6th Australian Division key assault force for Operation Compass. Captured Bardia fortress (3-5 Jan 1941) with 45,000 Italian POWs. Captured Tobruk fortress (21-22 Jan) with 25,000 Italian POWs and 462 guns. Pursued to Benghazi (6 Feb). Three infantry brigades (16th, 17th, 19th) at full strength. Supported by 7th RTR Matilda IIs for fortress assaults. High morale from continuous victories. Excellent combat readiness after successful operations.

historical_notes.classification: Australian Infantry Division (2nd Australian Imperial Force)
historical_notes.deployment: Operation Compass offensive - Bardia, Tobruk, Benghazi
historical_notes.q1_operations: Q1 1941 victories: Battle of Bardia (3-5 January) - division assaulted and captured fortress with 7th RTR Matilda support, 45,000 Italian POWs. Battle of Tobruk (21-22 January) - captured fortress, 25,000 POWs, 462 guns, 236 vehicles. Pursuit to Benghazi (February) completing destruction of Italian 10th Army. Division withdrawn to Egypt/Palestine late March for rest and refit after continuous combat January-March.
historical_notes.formation: Formed September 1939 as part of 2nd AIF (Australian Imperial Force volunteer expeditionary force). Deployed Middle East January 1940. First major combat Operation Compass December 1940-February 1941.
historical_notes.commander_notes: Major-General Iven Mackay commanded throughout Operation Compass. WWI veteran, highly regarded tactical commander. Division earned reputation as elite assault force.

sources.name: Australian War Memorial - 6th Division Operation Compass
Battle of Bardia - 6th Division assault 3-5 January 1941
Battle of Tobruk - 6th Division capture 21-22 January 1941

notes: Australian infantry division structure: 3 brigades, 9 battalions total
No organic armor (0 tanks) - supported by 7th RTR Matilda IIs during assaults
Q1 personnel (16,500) reflects full strength during Operation Compass
Commander: Iven Giffard Mackay (Major-General) throughout Q1 1941
Three major victories Q1: Bardia (45,000 POWs), Tobruk (25,000 POWs), Benghazi pursuit
Artillery: 72x 25-pdr field guns (3 regiments), 36x 2-pdr AT guns
Supply situation excellent: 12 days fuel, 20 days ammunition, 14 days water
Winter conditions favorable for offensive: 10-25°C temperatures
Withdrawn late March 1941 for rest/refit after continuous combat
Division later fought Greece, Syria, New Guinea campaigns
